div.head: Tagging for a digital edition
div.p:
In this exercise we'll revisit the Petrarch sonnet you worked on before. This time we will aim to produce a modern digital edition of the sonnet, by adding more tags specifically to :
mark the modernizations
add links to digital images of the manuscript
add notes, commentary, bibliography...

div.head: Modernization
div.p: Here's an image (kindly provided by the Bodleian Library) of one of the 16th manuscripts in which our Petrarchan sonnet has come down to us.

By comparison with this original manuscript, the text we are used to reading has been modernized in several ways. In the original document,
there is almost no punctuation and accented letters are used differently
certain words are spelled differently
We will reverse engineer our modernized text to produce a more diplomatic transcript, without losing the modernization information.

list.item: Using Oxygen, open the version of the sonnet you worked on in the first exercise. (If you've lost it, use the version we made for you, in the file Work/corr-petrarch.xml).
Also open the image file Work/petrach-detail.jpg and compare the two carefully.
First identify the words which have different spellings. (For example, in line 7, the word avea was originally written hauea)
Select the modern reading and surround the word with the tag reg (regularized); then insert an element orig and type the original reading into it.
Finally, select both elements, and surround them with a third one : choice.

div.head: Add links
div.p:
To associate our transcribed text with its digitized image file, the easiest method is as follows:
The poem starts at the beginning of a page, so we can insert an empty pb/ element in front of it. This tag can then be associated with the image file that begins here using the corresp attribute (the facs attribute would be better, but that is not available in the TEI Lite schema we are currently using)
The image file (petrarch.png) is in the same folder as our transcription, so we can point to it with a simple URI like this: <pb corresp="petrarch.png"/>. Alternatively, you could link directly to the image in the Bodleian Digital Library, using this link: <pb corresp="http://"/>

div.head: Add commentary
div.p:
You can add your own footnotes and commentary, using the tag note. For example :
Après l'élément quote, insérez une note comme ceci : "la Muse donne l'immortalité" (Horace, Carm IV, 29)
D'autres balises sont disponibles pour cette même note : par exemple gloss, bibl, author, title, biblStruct.
Vous pourriez aussi faire un lien entre la référence bibliographique et un URL tel que http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/horace/carm4.shtml
Don't forget to save your file! You'll need it in the next exercise.
